title: How to Bypass iCloud Activation Lock

steps.title: Reboot your iPhone or iPad.
steps.content: Reboot your iPhone or iPad. You’ll need to do this to access the setup menu, which is where you’ll find the login menu. If you've purchased a phone or tablet that's locked by the Apple ID of the previous owner, you'll need the owner's login info to use this method. If you can't be in the same room with the previous owner, they can perform a few steps on their own to release the lock.

steps.title: Tap Unlock with Passcode.
steps.content: Tap Unlock with Passcode . If you've reset your iPhone or iPad (or locked it using Find My iPhone), you can side-step the Activation Lock by signing in with your own passcode now. If you purchased this iPhone or iPad from someone who left their Apple ID signed in, the previous owner will need to log in using their own Apple ID and password. If you're not able to meet up with the previous owner in person, continue with this method. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Ask the previous owner to disconnect the iPhone or iPad from their account.
steps.content: Ask the previous owner to disconnect the iPhone or iPad from their account. Once you've gotten in touch with them, ask them to help with doing the following: Sign in to iCloud with their Apple ID. Go to Find My iPhone . Click All Devices at the top of the screen. Select your iPhone or iPad. Click Erase [device] . Click Remove from Account . Once they've removed their account, your iPhone or iPad will no longer be locked.

steps.title: Reboot your iPhone or iPad.
steps.content: Reboot your iPhone or iPad. You’ll need to do this to access the setup menu, which is where you’ll find the menu for inputting DNS bypass.

steps.title: Select your country and language.
steps.content: Select your country and language. Once you’ve done this, you’ll be directed to the Wi-Fi menu.

steps.title: Tap the i button next to the network you want to connect to.
steps.content: Tap the i button next to the network you want to connect to. This pulls up a new window with more information on the network.

steps.title: Scroll down to the DNS section and enter the IP addresses.
steps.content: Scroll down to the DNS section and enter the IP addresses. Once you’ve found this section, type these IP addresses into the field: 154.51.7 (North America), 155.28.90 (Europe), 155.220.58 (Asia), or 109.17.60 (rest of the world). [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the Back > button.
steps.content: Tap the Back > button. This will take you back to the Wi-Fi menu.

steps.title: Tap on your Wi-Fi network and enter the password.
steps.content: Tap on your Wi-Fi network and enter the password. Once you’re done, tap the Join button in the top-right corner.

steps.title: Tap the Back > button in the top-right.
steps.content: Tap the Back > button in the top-right. This will direct you back to the Wi-Fi page.

steps.title: Tap the Back > button again.
steps.content: Tap the Back > button again. Once you connect to your Wi-Fi network, the iOS device will try activating. You’ll need to press the Back button again to stop it from activating. Once you do this, you should see iCloudDNSBypass.net at the top of the page.

steps.title: Tap on the iCloudDNSBypass menu.
steps.content: Tap on the iCloudDNSBypass menu. From here, you can access apps that would help with identifying the user of the iPhone or iPad and figure out how to return or reconfigure the device.
